trustfund:
TF035586-MOROCCO - FISHERIES PROJECT AND
            GENERAL SECTOR WORKS

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory. Overall, the project has created a public
            awareness of the critical state of fisheries resources, and
            at the community level has empowered those stakeholders to
            organize and take legal action to protect the limited
            natural resources. The project established the legal,
            administrative, and institutional basis, and laid the
            foundation for further investment in the sub-sector.
            However, sustainability is rated as unlikely under the
            current circumstances. Lack of political will to enforce
            regulations and remedial measures, the weak leadership
            provided by the Department of Fisheries (DoF) and the
            problems of collaboration, unless resolved, will continue to
            hamper reforms and limit achievements of future operations.
            Consequently, the project can be considered to constitute a
            first phase of a longer-term effort in the sub-sector. The
            overall performance of both the Bank and the Borrower are
            evaluated as satisfactory.  Lessons learned included the
            following:   1) Success in formation of the Community-Based
            fisheries Management Committees (CBFMCs) depended on whether
            the communities were established or transient, and on the
            degree of collaboration and cooperation between DoF, the
            Ministry of Food and Agriculture (MOFA), and the district
            assemblies (DAs) in lending support to the communities to
            formulate management committees. 2) Although the limited
            capacity of the DoF was correctly ascertained at appraisal,
            the project designed was still complex, large and contained
            too many activities. 3)  The aquaculture pilot component was
            begun too late in the project to enable experience to be
            accumulated and reviewed. Technical, economic, commercial
            and socio-cultural data to support its development needed to
            be done before, not during, project implementation. An
            analysis will need to be done to determine the pilot
            centers' environmental impact and potential for
            attracting private sector investment before determining if
            they should move beyond the pilot scheme status. 4)
            Mitigation measures should have been more strongly built
            into project design and adjusted during implementation in a
            more forceful manner to offset the main risks to anticipated
            benefits which were institutional, financial, and
            biological. 5) An efficient monitoring and evaluation system
            as well as earlier implementation of the fisheries
            management plans would have benefited the project's
            outcome and improved its impact.. 6) The critical role that
            fisheries research plays in the management of limited
            resources suggests that it could have received more support
            for development and expansion under the project. In the
            future, more consideration will need to be given to how the
            various segments of the fishing sector could contribute to
            funding and monitoring of fisheries research. 7)
            Institutional strengthening and developing the capacity to
            manage natural resources are long-term objectives. Although
            the project laid the groundwork for these goals to be met,
            continued efforts will need to be made over the longer term
            beyond the project implementation period.
